content: vintage rippling block pattern after searching high and low for written instructions for this pattern my grandmother used to make i decided to write it up myself so everyone can enjoy it skill level easy stitches used chain slip_stitch double_crochet abbreviations used chain chain slip_stitch slip_stitch double_crochet double_crochet space space special terms block slip_stitch ch3 3dc in space indicated peak slip_stitch ch3 3dc ch3 3dc in space indicated notes change colors as often as desired gauge isn t important for this pattern you will want to make your first row 20-25% longer than the width you want since this is a ripple pattern and will become narrower after the first row with an h hook and worsted weight yarn one repeat of the pattern was 5 inches when making row 1 be sure to make a multiple of six blocks instructions row 1 chain 4 3 double_crochet in 4th chain from hook you will have a little block like this chain 4 3 double_crochet in 4th chain from hook now you have this continue making blocks in this manner that is chain 4 3dc in 4th chain from hook until you reach your desired width making sure you have a multiple of six blocks it will look something like this ch1 and turn row 2 slip_stitch in first ch3 space this is where your hook goes ch3 3dc in same ch3 space slip_stitch in next ch3 space ch3 3dc in same space make peak in next ch3 space it looks like this make block in next ch3 space twice now it should look like this slip_stitch in next ch3 space make block in next ch3 space twice make peak in next ch3 space make block in next ch3 space twice slip_stitch in next ch3 space across to end note you end with a slip_stitch ch1 and turn row 3 make block in next ch3 space twice make peak in next ch3 space make block in next ch3 space twice slip_stitch in next ch3 space repeat this across to end ch1 and turn repeat row three until desired length is reached add your favorite border if desired see how easy this is after row 1 working in your ch3 spaces it is just block block peak block block slip_stitch all the way across it couldn t be easier
